awd_titl_txt: Community Resources that Promote Mexican Origin Children's STEM Education across Diverse Families
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to broaden the participation of an important underrepresented group in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). Mexican-origin children, one of the fastest growing segments of the U.S. population, often come from disadvantaged circumstances that increase their need to use public education for social mobility while also posing challenges to navigating the public education system. Yet, Mexican-origin families are rich in social resources that can be leveraged to help children overcome obstacles in their educational paths. This project will identify critical points in the K-12 system and higher education when Mexican-origin children are at heightened vulnerability of leaving the STEM pipeline and community resources that promote their STEM persistence. Understanding the role that families and community resources play in Mexican-origin students' participation in STEM courses and careers is important for U.S. economic productivity and Mexican-origin children's economic success.

Organized around a conceptual model drawing from theories on life course, educational inequality, assimilation, cultural wealth, and community context, analyses will apply multilevel modeling to a new data source that integrates (1) the Early Childhood Longitudinal Study-Kindergarten Cohort of 1998-99 (covering the elementary to middle school transition) and the Educational Longitudinal Study of 2002 (covering the high school to college transition) with (2) community resources data from the National Center for Charitable Statistics, Institute of Museum & Library Services, Zip Business Patterns, and Bureau of Labor Statistics. This comprehensive data source will include a range of STEM outcomes at each pathway stage (test scores/gains, academic performance, course-taking, degree/certificate), community resources hypothesized to be supportive of Mexican-origin children's STEM education (nonprofit youth-serving or cultural organizations, libraries, businesses/labor market conditions), and measures of family context (SES, positive parenting). The merged databases will be available through the National Center of Education Statistics (NCES). The research team will also provide code written for statistical analyses upon request and permission from NCES. This project exemplifies the Education and Human Resources Core Research program's commitment to fundamental research on learning in STEM that combines theory, techniques, and perspectives from a wide range of disciplines and contexts. Further, by contributing to a cohesive, federated, national-scale approach to research data infrastructure, the project exemplifies NSF's larger aim of harnessing the data revolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
This project had three objectives: (1) identifying critical points in the K-12 system into higher education when Mexican-origin children are at heightened vulnerability of leaving STEM pursuits; (2) identifying community resources that promote their STEM progress at these key points; and (3) exploring differential patterns of association by family context.  To address these objectives, the project integrated two nationally representative datasets with sizeable Mexican-origin subsamples that allow for tracking STEM education from kindergarten through college (Early Childhood Longitudinal Study, Kindergarten Class of 1998-99 [ECLS-K] and Educational Longitudinal Study of 2002 [ELS]) with community-level data that tap STEM-relevant institutional resources beyond oft-studied sociodemographic factors (National Center for Charitable Statistics, Institute of Museum & Library Services, Zip Business Patterns, Bureau of Labor Statistics).  This resultant data source included a range of STEM outcomes at each stage of the educational pathway (i.e., test scores/gains, academic performance, course-taking, certificate/degree), community resources (i.e., non-profit organizations, libraries, businesses and labor market conditions) hypothesized to be supportive of STEM education in general and particularly for Mexican-origin children, and measures of risks and resources in the family context (low socioeconomic status [SES], positive parenting).

 

For the elementary-to-middle school transition, results suggest Mexican-immigrant children?s math achievement in grade 5 was most critical for their 8th grade math outcomes.  It may be that math achievement at this juncture, typically the end of elementary school, has enhanced significance because course offerings become more differentiated in middle school, typically based on ability, and may set some children up for more opportunities for STEM pursuits than others.  Progress made by the end of elementary school, especially as children gain language proficiency, may be more reflective of STEM potential than earlier math performance.  In light of growing concerns about inequities in STEM opportunities, these results have potential implications for schools in terms of course placements during the elementary-to-middle school transition.  Additional findings suggest the significance of educational non-profit organizations for Mexican immigrant children?s math achievement during this period. Furthermore, positive parenting reinforces the favorable role of STEM youth-serving organizations for the children?s math achievement, and general youth-serving organizations may serve a compensatory role when parenting is less effective.   The mixed results highlight the need for future research on resource access, usage, and quality and how to build effective family-neighborhood partnerships that bolster the benefits of these resources for Mexican-immigrant children?s STEM pursuits.  

 

For the high school-to-college transition, results suggest the highest math/science course level completed and end-of-school skills (math/science GPA and math test scores) are associated with youth from diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds pursuing both STEM and non-STEM post-secondary degrees. The availability of neighborhood resources, in particular, more minority and immigrant serving non-profit organizations and higher percentages of STEM occupations in the labor market, were associated with Mexican-origin, other Latino, and African American youth?s pursuit of post-secondary STEM degrees.  Related findings reveal that Mexican-origin youth who reside in established immigrant destinations had more positive STEM trajectories in high school than their peers in destinations where Latino/a immigration was newer.  Together, these finding highlight potential points and places to intervene in efforts to promote Mexican-origin youth?s STEM pursuits.

 

In sum, the goal of this project was to make major new contributions to efforts that broaden an underrepresented group?s STEM participation and improve their workforce preparation for this high-demand field.  Our results address for whom, when, and where STEM disparities arise among Mexican-origin children and point to how they may be mitigated. The finding provide information of value to broader discussions of inequality, STEM equity, and opportunities for economic and social mobility.

 


Last Modified: 08/25/2022
Modified by: Tama Leventhal

It may be that math achievement at this juncture, typically the end of elementary school, has enhanced significance because course offerings become more differentiated in middle school, typically based on ability, and may set some children up for more opportunities for STEM pursuits than others.  Progress made by the end of elementary school, especially as children gain language proficiency, may be more reflective of STEM potential than earlier math performance.  In light of growing concerns about inequities in STEM opportunities, these results have potential implications for schools in terms of course placements during the elementary-to-middle school transition. Furthermore, positive parenting reinforces the favorable role of STEM youth-serving organizations for the children?s math achievement, and general youth-serving organizations may serve a compensatory role when parenting is less effective. For the high school-to-college transition, results suggest the highest math/science course level completed and end-of-school skills (math/science GPA and math test scores) are associated with youth from diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds pursuing both STEM and non-STEM post-secondary degrees. Our results address for whom, when, and where STEM disparities arise among Mexican-origin children and point to how they may be mitigated. The finding provide information of value to broader discussions of inequality, STEM equity, and opportunities for economic and social mobility.
